Author: filiplaurentiu
Content: what is the derivation path for a stark key ?

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: We defined it for StarkEx (which required a different path per deployment)

Author: guthl_starkware
Content: We have not come up with one just yet for StarkNet

Author: guthl_starkware
Content:
For StarkEx, we had
m / purpose' / layer' / application' / eth_address_1' / eth_address_2' / index

Author: guthl_starkware
Content:
- m - the seed.
- purpose - 2645 (the number of this EIP).
- layer - the 31 lowest bits of sha256 on the layer name. Serve as a domain separator - between different technologies. In the context of starkex, the value would be 579218131.
- application - the 31 lowest bits of sha256 of the application name. Serve as a domain separator between different applications. In the context of DeversiFi in June 2020, it is the 31 lowest bits of sha256(starkexdvf) and the value would be 1393043894.
- eth_address_1 / eth_address_2 - the first and second 31 lowest bits of the corresponding eth_address.
- index - to allow multiple keys per eth_address.

Author: perama
Content:
Hey everyone just want to flag an issue with stale cache with `pytest`. 

When using `pytest` to test contracts there is automatic generation of `__pycache__` dir, containing `.pyc` files that mean files don't have to be compiled for every unit test you run.

However, this can cause a problem where the test suite fails to recognise when a contract has been updated. In particular, one specific example I notice that when importing a local Cairo file (e.g, a custom module), the cache doesn't update if you you delete the module and bring the functions in to the calling contract. The pytest module still uses the compiled contract that uses the external module. 

One potential solution is to manually delete the `.pyc` files in this instance. Another might be to use something like:

https://pypi.org/project/pyclean/

Anyone have better ideas?

Author: fabijanspaceshard
Content:
Changes:
- Enable passing constructor arguments (possible to pass them when calling `deploy` of a contract factory).
- Enable signing transactions.
- Rely on JS `BigInt` because Cairo's `felt` type might be too big for ordinary JS `Number`.
- Enforce typed/structured input and output (no more single-string function results; no more blindly passing sequences of numbers as function inputs).
- Fix Mac (OS X) support (when interacting with gateways listening on localhost, such as  `starknet-devnet`).

Examples:
Assume a contract with struct and function:
```text
struct Point:
    member x: felt
    member y: felt
end

func sum_points(p1: Point, p2: Point) -> (res: Point)
```
What used to look like:
```typescript
const resStr = await contract.call("sum_points", [1, 2, 3, 4]); // Point(1, 2) + Point(3, 4)
chai.expect(resStr).to.equal("4 6"); // Point(4, 6)
```
now looks like:
```typescript
const { res } = await contract.call("sum_points", { p1: { x: 1, y: 2 } , p2: { x: 3, y: 4 } });
chai.expect(res).to.deep.equal({ x: 4n, y: 6n }); // syntactic sugar for BigInt("4") and BigInt("6")
```
For more examples, check the project documentation.

Author: _sam___
Content:
Had some free time last night and decided to take a stab at a PoC package manager for Cairo. Distribution & installation handled by existing python tooling (pypi, pip, poetry, etc). Just a small utility to extract contract source code from modules registered to a python namespace package.

```
sam@sam:~/dev/eth/tmp$ python3.7 -m venv venv
sam@sam:~/dev/eth/tmp$ source venv/bin/activate
(venv) sam@sam:~/dev/eth/tmp$ pip install cairo-nile cairo-glyph cairo-placeholder
(venv) sam@sam:~/dev/eth/tmp$ nile init
(venv) sam@sam:~/dev/eth/tmp$ glyph use --all
🔎 Discovering installed contracts...

 • Using contracts.placeholder

✅ Done.

# Contract source now vendored into a contracts/lib directory
(venv) sam@sam:~/dev/eth/tmp$ tree contracts/
contracts/
├── contract.cairo
└── libs
    └── placeholder
        └── contract.cairo

```

Ofc needs a ton more tweaking / standardization of imports and all that. This was just to quickly play around with one potential strategy for distributing .cairo files, leveraging as much of existing tools as possible

https://github.com/sambarnes/cairo-glyph

@udayj It is easy to make errors using the Starknet CLI. Using https://github.com/Shard-Labs/starknet-hardhat-plugin allows you to make simpler CLI calls with the same functionality. npx hardhat starknet-compile

Author: martriay
Content:
ah, I see what you mean. yes, my idea was to have a single entry point for Account contracts for a few reasons:
- to minimize the codebase therefore the attack/bug surface of the contract
- to avoid having a different function than `__execute__` that handles tx validation (\*) and nonce management. this would not only be duplicated logic (even if it's calling a function) but it also makes a more complex contract, and we need this contract to be super secure
- it's a design statement. if there's other account implementations with other user-facing functions, they should be routed through execute. this makes a much simpler mental model both for wallets and users.
- elegance ✨ 


(*) probably that will be moved to `__validate__` but the point still holds

Author: martriay
Content: i hear what you say about an extra `call_contract` call. not convinced that outweighs the benefits of a simpler model

Author: laurip
Content: thanks for the analysis 🙂 Yes I agree it's elegant and makes sense. But it has these drawbacks as well.

Author: laurip
Content: adding an extra "if calling locally, then call it like this, but if call is external use call_contract" makes it less elegant and opens new attack vectors

Author: bowlofchilli
Content: OpenZeppelin related: would using view methods on proxiable implementations require transactions? Going by the documentation below

Author: bowlofchilli
Content:
As with most StarkNet contracts, interacting with a proxy contract requires an account abstraction. One notable difference with proxy contracts versus other contract implementations is that calling @view methods also requires an account abstraction. As of now, direct calls to default entrypoints are only supported by StarkNet's syscalls from other contracts i.e. account contracts. The differences in getter methods written in Python, for example, are as follows:
# standard ERC20 call
result = await erc20.totalSupply().call()

# upgradeable ERC20 call
result = await signer.send_transaction(
        account, PROXY.contract_address, 'totalSupply', []
    )

Author: haroune_foo
Content: Hello everyone, We're writing tests for our cairo contracts using Python and starknet-dev and we hit a blocked road regarding internal functions, I'm wondering how the community is testing internal functions ? Thanks in advance

Author: milan3774
Content: we have a `test_foo.cairo` file in which we wrap all the internal functions we want to test as `@external` and use the `test_foo` to interact with them

Author: pilou_sekai
Content:
I don't test internal internal functions. Coming from a web 2.0 back-end software engineering background, I don't like the idea to test private, internal in case of Cairo, methods as these are, for me, implementation details and should be tested via public, here external, methods.
For me, unit testing should be focused on testing the outputs/inputs of a contract. Testing the actual implementation defeats this purpose as the tests know about the implementation and not the interface. If you test all your external methods with the right inputs and have full coverage, then you shouldn't need to test the internal ones imo. 
Maybe this way of thinking is not really transferrable to smart contracts and the way they are written. If anyone has a different take on this, I'd be happy to hear it ! 🙂

Author: eni7912
Content:
I don't really agree with that, I think it's not necessary to test everything, but when internal functions are critical components of an app and have complex behavior they should be tested to ensure their correctness. e.g I have a math library that makes calculations, I need to test all edge cases (overflows, limits, correctness, rounding, etc) and for that I wouldn't rely on testing contract entries

+ tracking down a bug in a unit test is *a lot* easier than trying to figure out why the output of a smart contract call is not correct
And also I think that in smart contract development we should test as many things as possible, as long as it makes sense to test it. I read somewhere that a 30-35% dev - 65-70% test ratio was good and I tend to agree.

Author: augustbleeds
Content:
You'll need hardhat with the hardhat starknet plugin in order to run a local devnet and run unit tests on it (I believe it will depend on starknet-devnet). Hardhat starknet plugin should now support cairo 1.0. However, if you don't need to run a local devnet, you can probably cover most unit tests using cairo test which is much faster. Scarb is useful for package management though.

You can use all of them together though. I'd recommend scarb as a framework, writing unit tests in cairo, and if you need to, using hardhat for integration testing between L1 and L2.

Author: glihm
Content: There is no "wallet" address on Starknet. Everything is contract address, including your account. A wallet is just a software that manage your cryptographic keys. 👍

Author: glihm
Content:
At the moment devnet is being re-written in rust, so I think it will be better to have a look at it once it's re-written and more featured. I don't know the state actually of the devnet in rust.

Katana is up to date with latest starknet versions in rust and sequencer library (the blockifier). So you've a very close execution from what actually happens on chain.

Author: ghonghito
Content: okay but check this on starkscan... wallet page it says "ACCOUNT" on contract page its says "UNKNOWN"

Author: glihm
Content:
The reason of that is because yes, Account **ARE** a class of contract. 🙂
Unknown is then here to mention that the contract's class (which is the code being related to the contract) is not identified.

This is only possible by comparing a database of known class hash. 👍

Author: glihm
Content: Well, technically, you can make some calls to a contract to check which functions it exposes, and you can determine if it's an account or not. Soon the great project on-going with OZ about interfaces will help a lot for this matter.
